Would you like to inspect the original subtitles? These are the user uploaded subtitles that are being translated: 1 00:00:17,367 --> 00:00:23,667 "Art is a lie that makes us realise truth" 2 00:00:33,392 --> 00:00:37,813 The Adventures of Picasso 3 00:00:37,814 --> 00:00:43,057 A thousand loving lies told by Hans Alfredson & Tage Danielsson 4 00:00:43,058 --> 00:00:45,979 Picasso paintings recreated by Per Ahlin 5 00:00:45,980 --> 00:00:51,516 Made in "AB svenska ords ateljeer" in Hollywood close to Tomelilla [Sweden] 6 00:00:51,517 --> 00:00:56,712 All similarities between this film and reality are entirely coincidental. 7 00:00:57,791 --> 00:01:01,160 Hello, My name is Elsa Beskow and I'm going... 8 00:01:01,161 --> 00:01:03,824 to tell you about one of my colleges in the art world... 9 00:01:07,581 --> 00:01:11,423 Nobody know the exact hour of his birth... 10 00:01:11,528 --> 00:01:14,919 It was either at 5 PM 11 00:01:14,950 --> 00:01:17,003 "alas cinco de la tarde" 12 00:01:19,213 --> 00:01:23,949 or during the midnight hour, which he himself claimed... 13 00:01:23,950 --> 00:01:27,583 He, one of the strangest men of our time... 14 00:01:27,890 --> 00:01:34,128 He, a descendent of the 16th century knight... 15 00:01:34,129 --> 00:01:35,417 "Juan de Leon" 16 00:01:35,418 --> 00:01:38,880 Who was killed in the war between Loja and Granada 17 00:01:38,881 --> 00:01:41,985 He, Pablo Picasso... 18 00:01:41,986 --> 00:01:45,347 whom was born in Malaga almost a century ago 19 00:02:56,640 --> 00:03:01,174 Pablo was brought up in the poor area of Malaga 20 00:03:01,690 --> 00:03:04,415 His mother - Dona Maria - was... 21 00:03:04,452 --> 00:03:05,925 Happy 22 00:03:05,927 --> 00:03:06,883 Tender 23 00:03:06,884 --> 00:03:08,394 Independent 24 00:03:08,395 --> 00:03:09,831 Sensitive 25 00:03:09,832 --> 00:03:11,121 Warm blooded 26 00:03:11,122 --> 00:03:12,300 Proud 27 00:03:12,302 --> 00:03:14,091 and affectionate 28 00:03:14,092 --> 00:03:17,580 But his father - Don Jose - was very sloppy in his work 29 00:03:23,162 --> 00:03:27,960 The young Pablo Picasso soon proved to be quite artistic. 30 00:03:35,917 --> 00:03:40,694 The proud father decided to introduce him to the art-academy in Madrid 31 00:03:50,511 --> 00:03:55,447 "The rain in Spain stays mainly in the plain" 32 00:08:00,912 --> 00:08:04,223 There was a genie in the bottle 33 00:08:04,263 --> 00:08:08,936 a magical force that would make his art come to live 34 00:09:16,088 --> 00:09:20,319 The education at the academy was academic 35 00:15:15,275 --> 00:15:19,761 Neither of his parents could ever come to grips with... 36 00:15:19,762 --> 00:15:22,511 Don Jose's near death experience. 37 00:15:22,908 --> 00:15:27,441 The tension at home grew odious for the young artist... 38 00:15:27,442 --> 00:15:29,311 and he decided to leave. 39 00:18:58,236 --> 00:19:02,347 It was the new years eve of 1899 40 00:19:03,259 --> 00:19:08,402 The Parisians outside celebrated with Champagne... 41 00:19:08,878 --> 00:19:11,911 dancing in the streets and fire-works. 42 00:19:42,010 --> 00:19:44,044 Paris 1910 43 00:19:45,103 --> 00:19:49,000 Pablo Picasso was still poor and hungry 44 00:19:49,579 --> 00:19:52,061 He paints and paints and paints 45 00:19:52,386 --> 00:19:56,542 But selling and selling and selling he is NOT 46 00:22:38,274 --> 00:22:40,835 That was the birth of Cubism 47 00:23:30,766 --> 00:23:34,999 Picasso returned to the vagabonds in the circus world... 48 00:23:35,155 --> 00:23:38,481 These warm hearted artistic souls... 49 00:23:38,484 --> 00:23:42,549 whom - free of charge - gave there pathetic faces... 50 00:23:42,550 --> 00:23:44,372 to the artist 51 00:27:09,973 --> 00:27:13,904 The American author Gertrude Stein's salon... 52 00:27:13,936 --> 00:27:18,061 was the center of the French art world... 53 00:27:18,532 --> 00:27:20,766 and her constant companion... 54 00:27:20,768 --> 00:27:22,837 her chaperon 55 00:27:23,066 --> 00:27:24,678 Alice B. Toklas 56 00:28:55,519 --> 00:29:00,134 Now Picasso was at the center of the Parisian art world... 57 00:29:00,198 --> 00:29:02,195 with people such as [Georges] Braque... 58 00:29:02,230 --> 00:29:03,050 [Henri] Matisse... 59 00:29:03,069 --> 00:29:05,145 Fernand Lege... 60 00:29:05,147 --> 00:29:06,849 Pompidou... 61 00:29:06,850 --> 00:29:08,346 entrecote... 62 00:29:08,347 --> 00:29:09,958 Carl Larsson... 63 00:29:09,959 --> 00:29:11,287 Popeye [Karl-Alfred]... 64 00:29:19,468 --> 00:29:20,900 Jenny Nystrom... 65 00:29:23,582 --> 00:29:25,052 an omelette... 66 00:29:25,053 --> 00:29:27,057 and Rembrandt 67 00:29:31,575 --> 00:29:35,618 And there is Hemingway sitting with his knitting 68 00:29:36,421 --> 00:29:41,648 There was also a Erik Satie the often misunderstood composer 69 00:29:43,192 --> 00:29:47,928 Guillaume Apollinaire, the absurdist poet... 70 00:29:54,241 --> 00:29:58,795 Henri Rousseau, the painting customs officer 71 00:30:02,430 --> 00:30:06,725 Vincent van Gogh, the guy with the ear 72 00:30:09,265 --> 00:30:12,944 And not less than two Toulouse-Lautrec 73 00:30:23,553 --> 00:30:25,535 And the famous Mimi... 74 00:30:25,536 --> 00:30:30,110 the woman that inspired Puccini to write "your hands are so cold" 75 00:34:49,203 --> 00:34:55,575 What is a man, or even an artist other than a small flake... 76 00:34:55,577 --> 00:34:59,198 in the vast and silent universe? 77 00:35:02,607 --> 00:35:03,688 Well then! 78 00:35:04,880 --> 00:35:09,385 Let's stop for a minute to examine the regular life... 79 00:35:09,386 --> 00:35:11,842 of a lonely artist in the 1910's 80 00:35:12,262 --> 00:35:15,712 Is there anything lonelier then a genius? 81 00:35:18,009 --> 00:35:22,061 Th... that is relatively lonelier than a genius? 82 00:35:25,189 --> 00:35:28,321 He rose early in the morning, put on his clothes... 83 00:35:30,237 --> 00:35:33,381 humming of a cheerful morning-song... 84 00:35:38,333 --> 00:35:39,941 and then he went outside... 85 00:35:40,275 --> 00:35:43,553 to prepare himself for an intensive workday... 86 00:35:43,628 --> 00:35:47,312 with a long brisk walk in "Bois de Boulogne" 87 00:35:51,054 --> 00:35:52,100 LONG 88 00:35:55,156 --> 00:35:56,410 BRISK! 89 00:35:58,400 --> 00:36:00,795 He stopped every now and then... 90 00:36:01,345 --> 00:36:03,821 to "skissa" [skissa similar to kissa=urinate] 91 00:36:06,262 --> 00:36:08,208 Skissa=To sketch 92 00:36:15,871 --> 00:36:19,285 Here the master is painting a pair of eyeglasses 93 00:36:20,813 --> 00:36:22,656 A... a bicycle... 94 00:36:25,215 --> 00:36:27,349 Eh... an elk 95 00:36:28,338 --> 00:36:29,394 A painting! 96 00:36:31,034 --> 00:36:34,358 Pablo Picasso continued wrestling with his art 97 00:36:55,392 --> 00:36:57,974 The Swedish-American multi-millionaire... 98 00:36:57,975 --> 00:37:00,850 Ingrid Svensson-Guggenheim loved art... 99 00:37:02,377 --> 00:37:03,769 and artists 100 00:38:22,363 --> 00:38:24,029 Ingrid Svensson-Guggenheim... 101 00:38:24,030 --> 00:38:27,309 was one of the many people that didn't understand Picasso's work... 102 00:38:27,310 --> 00:38:30,925 but she knew it was expensive, hence immortal. 103 00:38:53,475 --> 00:38:56,284 Ingrid Svensson-Guggenheim became a persistent pester for Picasso 104 00:38:56,285 --> 00:38:59,630 She strived to be part of his life and work, at any price 105 00:39:30,828 --> 00:39:34,706 He fled to the tranquility of nature 106 00:39:44,486 --> 00:39:46,931 It's not easy being famous. 107 00:40:25,398 --> 00:40:27,520 To make his friend happy... 108 00:40:27,521 --> 00:40:29,710 the kind-hearted Rousseau invited Pablo... 109 00:40:29,711 --> 00:40:33,922 and Apollinaire to his secret forest... 110 00:40:33,923 --> 00:40:40,293 where no human-being had set foot except Rousseau himself. 111 00:40:54,916 --> 00:41:00,416 Guillaume Apollinaire read one of his deeply philosophical poems... 112 00:41:00,417 --> 00:41:02,217 about the human essence, 113 00:41:42,329 --> 00:41:47,545 This was to be the onset to the memorable masquerade ball... 114 00:41:47,546 --> 00:41:51,985 which Picasso held in his salon, in honour of his friend Rousseau. 115 00:42:23,896 --> 00:42:26,181 What a fabulous crowd! 116 00:42:26,182 --> 00:42:28,095 There was Jean Cocteau... 117 00:42:28,096 --> 00:42:29,680 Enrico Caruso 118 00:42:35,427 --> 00:42:38,116 Braque and Matisse was seen off the shelf 119 00:42:38,117 --> 00:42:40,142 Marie and Pierre Curie 120 00:42:40,143 --> 00:42:44,177 [Alexander] Graham Bell, the inventor of the telephone-kiosk 121 00:42:45,575 --> 00:42:50,033 Emperor Wilhem II was dancing with his elegant wife 122 00:42:52,243 --> 00:42:53,533 Lenin 123 00:42:54,270 --> 00:42:56,406 And the young Winston Churchill 124 00:43:00,202 --> 00:43:05,542 Even the French president was there, dressed as a balloon 125 00:43:11,842 --> 00:43:16,508 It was an unforgettable farewell party for Rousseau... 126 00:43:16,509 --> 00:43:20,490 the little customs officer, the king of imagination! 127 00:46:36,537 --> 00:46:39,411 The year was 1914 128 00:46:43,283 --> 00:46:46,705 The future had never looked so bright... 129 00:46:49,174 --> 00:46:52,341 workers and artists joined together... 130 00:46:52,482 --> 00:46:55,424 people would never stand against each other... 131 00:46:55,425 --> 00:47:01,650 faith in the international solidarity was equally strong as... 132 00:47:01,652 --> 00:47:04,782 the faith in the blessing of the industrial era. 133 00:47:09,948 --> 00:47:14,073 The optimistic view of development in the future was stronger than ever... 134 00:47:14,074 --> 00:47:16,653 The machines were supposed to save the world! 135 00:47:21,098 --> 00:47:22,325 Freedom [Liberté] 136 00:47:23,164 --> 00:47:24,388 Equality [Egalité] 137 00:47:25,369 --> 00:47:27,174 Fraternity [Fraternité] 138 00:47:27,986 --> 00:47:30,012 Would at long last come true 139 00:47:31,042 --> 00:47:31,964 In short... 140 00:47:33,253 --> 00:47:35,132 it was the time of a new dawn. 141 00:50:01,062 --> 00:50:03,854 There would never be another war... 142 00:50:03,855 --> 00:50:09,233 a new generation of artists came to Paris to build a better world. 143 00:53:08,750 --> 00:53:12,729 And that's why Picasso made decorations and costumes... 144 00:53:12,730 --> 00:53:15,087 for the famous Russian ballet 145 00:53:23,557 --> 00:53:28,014 Djagilev's production, Erik Satie's music and... 146 00:53:28,015 --> 00:53:31,218 Picasso's decor would dumbfound the world. 147 00:53:44,665 --> 00:53:47,687 The world premiere was in London. 148 00:55:05,491 --> 00:55:08,437 It was three hours before the premiere... 149 00:55:08,438 --> 00:55:11,974 the tension was high. 150 00:58:05,259 --> 00:58:08,981 Picasso had had enough with the foul stench of high society 151 00:58:08,983 --> 00:58:12,902 He fled from Djagilev and Olga 152 00:58:18,283 --> 00:58:22,435 He hid in a little obscure cabaret in Monparnas, Paris 153 01:00:56,105 --> 01:00:59,528 Picasso was spellbound by Sirkka's singing... 154 01:01:00,357 --> 01:01:03,280 and it would lead him to his destiny 155 01:02:35,714 --> 01:02:37,028 She wasn't home. 156 01:06:38,471 --> 01:06:41,754 That was the birth of "Monster-ism" 157 01:07:16,999 --> 01:07:22,073 Picasso and his father fled to New York 158 01:08:01,754 --> 01:08:04,798 New York, the big apple 159 01:09:02,474 --> 01:09:06,831 There was a prohibition on alcohol during the 1930's... 160 01:09:06,832 --> 01:09:10,213 after the ban on alcohol there was a ban on art... 161 01:09:15,964 --> 01:09:18,163 artists went underground... 162 01:09:18,164 --> 01:09:23,535 Picasso created the forbidden poison with a pencil stoke. 163 01:09:29,878 --> 01:09:33,380 During the great art prohibition in America... 164 01:09:33,389 --> 01:09:39,214 the federal police defused this menace... 165 01:09:41,837 --> 01:09:45,306 the police imposed constant raids... 166 01:09:57,824 --> 01:10:01,165 a remarkable job is done thanks to "art-dogs"... 167 01:10:01,166 --> 01:10:06,156 Here's Jackie, specialising in maritime motifs. 168 01:10:11,948 --> 01:10:16,152 There's a golden era for the smuggling business. 169 01:10:16,490 --> 01:10:18,816 Isn't it Mr. Guggenheim... 170 01:10:18,817 --> 01:10:23,257 Ingrid Svensson- Guggenheim's husband 171 01:10:25,361 --> 01:10:28,935 There is a steady flow of art in all shapes and sizes... 172 01:10:28,936 --> 01:10:31,273 from the Canadian border. 173 01:10:31,761 --> 01:10:35,262 "Beauty is the opium for the people"... 174 01:10:35,263 --> 01:10:37,619 Franklin D. Roosevelt proclaims... 175 01:10:37,620 --> 01:10:40,345 and receives support from his completely legal wife. 176 01:11:18,122 --> 01:11:22,947 Don Jose had established himself as "The French Connection"... 177 01:11:22,948 --> 01:11:28,915 between the American crime syndicates and the French artist. 178 01:11:29,775 --> 01:11:37,622 One day Picasso himself had to deliver paintings to a "Mrs. X". 179 01:11:59,216 --> 01:12:02,347 Ingrid Svensson-Guggenheim didn't give up that easily. 180 01:14:00,654 --> 01:14:04,066 Ingrid Svensson-Guggenheim introduced Picasso to different... 181 01:14:04,067 --> 01:14:08,732 camouflaged underground galleries, where rivaling... 182 01:14:08,733 --> 01:14:12,195 gangsters operated their "big business". 183 01:16:43,402 --> 01:16:46,091 [Translating to Swedish] 184 01:18:52,429 --> 01:18:57,091 [Norwegian accent] 185 01:21:51,515 --> 01:21:53,985 It was the late 1930's... 186 01:21:53,988 --> 01:22:00,470 Picasso returned to a Europe where savages rose yet again. 187 01:23:08,706 --> 01:23:13,230 The Germans marched in to Paris the spring of 1940. 188 01:23:54,330 --> 01:23:59,558 Quite surprisingly, Picasso collaborated with the Germans... 189 01:23:59,559 --> 01:24:02,470 by designing their camouflaged uniforms. 190 01:24:08,795 --> 01:24:14,874 They soon started to suspect that Picasso wasn't really on their side. 191 01:24:14,875 --> 01:24:19,554 But Picasso - unlike some of his friends - stayed in Europe. 192 01:24:19,555 --> 01:24:22,684 One day, while sitting in his cold studio... 193 01:24:22,685 --> 01:24:25,336 eating a cake that he got from... 194 01:24:25,337 --> 01:24:28,433 the black market in exchange for a "petit genre" [painting]... 195 01:24:28,434 --> 01:24:31,232 portraying "The rape of the Sabine women"... 196 01:24:51,361 --> 01:24:56,262 Don Jose had risen to the rank of "Hauptbahnhof" in SS... 197 01:24:56,264 --> 01:24:58,805 he was in charge of "operation ostrich"... 198 01:24:58,806 --> 01:25:02,046 which was supposed to track down members of the opposition. 199 01:25:02,047 --> 01:25:06,983 He had told his son not to get involved in any "risky business". 200 01:27:44,134 --> 01:27:45,570 Peace finally arrived 201 01:28:28,122 --> 01:28:32,177 Pablo was tired of the-old-era, settled down in the Riviera. 202 01:29:06,789 --> 01:29:08,815 You little man... 203 01:29:11,320 --> 01:29:14,564 you've already decided between capitalism and socialism... 204 01:29:16,480 --> 01:29:20,605 well, well, well, but you live like a capitalist at any rate... 205 01:29:22,227 --> 01:29:25,763 you don't exactly hang out with proletarians... 206 01:29:35,832 --> 01:29:39,871 well, well, well, you believe in equality... 207 01:29:39,872 --> 01:29:43,666 However, do you really think people have as much as you? 208 01:29:44,844 --> 01:29:47,239 There is a difference... 209 01:29:47,718 --> 01:29:51,033 between what those fishermen over there earn... 210 01:29:52,948 --> 01:29:54,975 and what you get paid. 211 01:29:58,107 --> 01:30:02,489 It's not your fault that the prices on your paintings are high... 212 01:30:04,370 --> 01:30:07,022 and it's not your fault that fish is so cheap either... 213 01:30:07,023 --> 01:30:09,380 and you can't refuse to take the money since... 214 01:30:09,381 --> 01:30:11,884 the art dealer would just use it to buy another Cadillac. 215 01:30:12,871 --> 01:30:15,635 You're just too good. 216 01:30:19,096 --> 01:30:21,639 But what are you doing to change the world? 217 01:30:23,702 --> 01:30:25,434 Well, you make pictures. 218 01:30:26,317 --> 01:30:29,228 Everybody needs art and beauty. 219 01:30:30,260 --> 01:30:33,611 Those fishermen also need art and beauty. 220 01:31:04,554 --> 01:31:06,545 No, don't look around! 221 01:31:06,546 --> 01:31:09,122 Be happy, otherwise you can't work. 222 01:31:09,123 --> 01:31:11,334 Skal, my friend! 223 01:33:56,052 --> 01:34:00,693 And so Picasso met the love of his youth 224 01:34:00,694 --> 01:34:02,977 the mysterious Dolores... 225 01:34:02,978 --> 01:34:07,729 who lived in exile with the fishermen in the Riviera... 226 01:34:08,770 --> 01:34:14,848 and her granddaughter had a strange influence on him. 227 01:34:27,447 --> 01:34:30,653 Picasso's doves flew over the world... 228 01:34:30,654 --> 01:34:33,932 in the cold winds of the cold war. 229 01:37:05,804 --> 01:37:09,610 Ingrid Svensson-Guggenheim didn't give up that easily... 230 01:48:14,039 --> 01:48:16,274 It was the great "Picasso crash"... 231 01:48:16,275 --> 01:48:18,324 which created panic at the stock-exchange... 232 01:48:18,325 --> 01:48:20,585 when the signatures suddenly disappeared... 233 01:48:20,586 --> 01:48:23,053 his painting was put on sale at the art auctions... 234 01:48:23,054 --> 01:48:25,621 100 Picasso's for one Donald Duck... 235 01:48:25,622 --> 01:48:29,232 His paintings was hurled away to the scrapheap. 236 01:48:29,233 --> 01:48:31,404 Art became "soft currency". 237 01:48:31,405 --> 01:48:33,578 People started buying collectable dinner plates... 238 01:48:33,579 --> 01:48:35,787 and pendants with the king and queen on them. 239 01:48:37,446 --> 01:48:41,866 It echoed in the bank vaults from the falling art collectors. 240 01:48:42,898 --> 01:48:44,850 In short, chaos. 241 01:48:54,732 --> 01:48:56,702 How the hell should I know? 17959
